title: HW4 Q4
content: Context: This problem (the latter parts of which are from an old exam) serves as a practical exercise in determining the size of feature maps and number of parameters in CNN layers in a general convolutional layer. You will also compute the effect of operations such as max-pooling and downsampling on output feature shape and number of parameters in a specific CNN architecture.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>For part d I am confused about the meaning of this sentence<break/><break/>"For example, if we apply a max pooling layer with a kernel size of 2 and a stride of 2, we increase the output feature size by a factor of 2."<break/><break/>My understanding is that max pooling operation takes a max over the spatial dimensions for each channel: converting (H, W, C) -> (1,1,C). How can this expand the C dimension simultaneously? It seems to me that we would need an additional conv layer with C+N filters to expand the dimension, no?</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
For part d I am confused about the meaning of this sentence

"For example, if we apply a max pooling layer with a kernel size of 2 and a stride of 2, we increase the output feature size by a factor of 2."

My understanding is that max pooling operation takes a max over the spatial dimensions for each channel: converting (H, W, C) -> (1,1,C). How can this expand the C dimension simultaneously? It seems to me that we would need an additional conv layer with C+N filters to expand the dimension, no?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I think the context for this sentence is that because max pooling would cause spatial info loss, we will need to increase the output channel to compensate for that loss (like you mentioned, adding additional filters), instead of increasing output channel is a result of max pooling.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
